social_posts.post_text:
Life as a Biology Student 🧫🧬

Uhmm anyone else blank out when people ask them the simplest questions about biology? 

I know I do 🙋‍♀️ 

One time my manager asked me how does a T cell know that their is at antigen. I literally stood there for 5 minutes in silence (while he contemplates why he hired me) before I have him the answer 😂

I can confidently talk about all my work, especially my work with oncology and crispr! But when it comes to simple questions, I even forget my name under pressure 😅😅

That is why #GOOGLE is your best friend 😂

Follow 👉 @labskillsacademy for relatable science videos 🧠🧫

Credits: to the original audio creator (idk why I cant tag her) 
.
.
.
#science #sciencememes #scientist #sciencereels #biotech #biotechstudent #biology #biologymemes #biologystudent #labwork #reels #computer

✨INTRODUCTION ✨:

Hello to all my followers 👋 

I realized I never fully introduced myself 😅 My name is Marie, I’m 24 and I work in a biotechnology company in Boston 🇺🇸 that focuses on genome engineering 🧬 My work focuses on inserting genetic sequences at any location in the genome. I’m really excited to see how far this technology is going to go and how many people we can help by delivering cures to patients 👩‍⚕️

I have a MSc in Molecular Biotechnology and a BS in Biology. Some classes I took include, Molecular Biology, Microbiology, Biochemistry, Organic Chemistry etc … 🧪🧫

I started labskillsacademy because I felt like as a scientist in the field I did not have enough information on how to get a jump start in the field. So I made this platform to help other people in the field learn more about science and see what other opportunities are out there. I like to share fun facts about science and help others learn. I am really passionate about science and always looking for what’s new 👀

I love to workout 🏋️‍♀️ , read 📖, trying out new restaurants 🍔, travel ✈️, and of course being in the lab 🥼 🧫

Introduce yourself in the comments! ⬇️

Just another day culturing cells in the lab 🧫 🥼

Cell culture is 70% of my work in the lab 🧫 I tend to change media, passage cells, thaw & plate cells, engineer cells, transfect etc … 

Take a look into my life 🌎 I hope everyone is having a great day and shoutout to all the new followers 🫶

What does your day look like?

🚨 Job Alerts 🚨 

These jobs were posted 24 hrs ago, for job positions around the US 🇺🇸 

Lab Associate Qualifications: Bachelor degree, experience 1-3 years 

Research Associate: Bachelor degree, experience 1-3 years 

Associate Scientist I: Bachelor degree, 3-5 years experience or MS degree, 2-3 years experience 

Senior Scientist: PhD 3-5 years industry experience

Scientist: MS degree, 5-7 years experience or PhD, 1-3 years industry experience

Looking for Lab Experience ? 

LinkedIn/ ResearchGate: Are platforms that post several lab positions and internships. Create profiles and set alerts to receive notifications 🔔 

University Labs: Many universities have research labs where professors and researchers welcome undergraduate students as volunteers or for credit. Speak to professors in your department or check the university’s research opportunities.

Summer Schools: STEM summer schools include in their curriculum lab experience! 

Co-op/ internships: Many companies especially in the biotech and pharmaceutical industries, offer internships for students. Check their websites! 

Hospitals/ Medical Centers: If you’re interested in healthcare-related research, consider reaching out to hospitals and medical centers. They may have labs focused on clinical research.

Save this post for late 🔖

The big question everyone asks! 

Academia or Industry? 

People tend to say that people work in Industry have it easy. While people working in Academia suffer real bad. 

There are a lot of factors that have to play into that. So evaluate your criteria and what you value most, before pursuing anything. 

This reel was made just for fun. But remember what ever path you choose, does not make you any less of a scientist. It’s your path and your career. Do what makes you happy. 

Thanks @aamir.phd for your great acting skills 🎬 If you want PhD tips, he’s the guy you need to follow! 

🧬

If it were easy, then anyone can do it ✨

If you are doubting yourself or going through a rough time just know we’ve all been there 🙋‍♀️🙋🙋‍♂️

In the world of STEM there are days when you are going to feel stupid, or naive, or mediocre, or like you do not fit in. 
You might feel like you are not smart enough, or question your life decisions ⁉️

Just know, that breaking into this field requires a lot of patience and forgiveness. 
You might wonder who should you forgive? You should forgive yourself for ever doubting, sabotaging, and undermining. 

Nothing is a straight road, but if you keep on working and believing. You will get there. ✨✨✨

My dream was to move to Boston and work in Biotech to help make a difference in the world. It took some time, but I am there now 🫶

Did you think Biotech was a boring industry? 🥱 Well think again! 

Drug Safety Associate: 
May be involved in activities such as collecting and analyzing data on adverse events, preparing reports, and communicating with health care professionals.

Pharmacovigilance Officer:
As a pharmacovigilance officer, you will be responsible for monitoring the safety of pharmaceutical products.

Medical Science Liaison:
A medical science liaison (MSL) is a pharmaceutical representative who works with healthcare professionals to provide educational information about a company’s products. MSLs typically work in the field, visiting doctors and other healthcare professionals to discuss the latest research on a particular medication or disease. 

Product Manager:
As a product manager, you will be responsible for the planning, development, and execution of marketing plans for a specific pharmaceutical product. You will work closely with sales, marketing, and medical teams to develop strategies that will increase product awareness and market share.

Regulatory Affairs Specialist: 
Is responsible for ensuring that a company’s products are in compliance with all applicable laws and regulations. 

Sales Representative:
Sales representatives are responsible for promoting and selling a company’s products. They often travel to meet with clients and attend industry events. This job is perfect for individuals who are outgoing and enjoy meeting new people.

Travel Pharmacist:
Travel pharmacy is a great industry for travelers. It’s even in the name! Travel pharmacists fill in at pharmacies all around the country.

Life Science Interviews Can be stressful 😓😫

I got you on how to answer difficult questions in a smooth way 💁‍♀️

1) In tough job interviews, honesty is best. If you don’t know an answer, admit it, but don’t dwell on it. Quickly shift to something you’re good at, and highlight your skills and strengths.

2) Here’s a simpler version:

When you’re unsure how to answer a question, it’s okay to ask the interviewer to clarify or explain it better. Often, this will lead them to a topic you’re more comfortable with. Focus your response on that part instead of the challenging one. If you still can’t answer after clarification, consider the next step.

3) To show you’re not afraid of not knowing an answer, begin with a positive tone when faced with a challenging question. Say something like, “I’m glad you asked about that!” It sets a good impression, even if you’re about to admit a skill gap.

Then, express your enthusiasm for learning more about the topic and discuss your plans for improving in that area. You can even ask the interviewer if they can provide support for your growth in this new area. This turns the conversation into a discussion about your professional development with their company, rather than just admitting a lack of experience.

Let me know which one’s your favorite ? 👆
🧬
🧬
🧬
#biotechlab #interview #lifescience #stemeducation #stemcell #biotech #biotechusa #labtech #labinterview #industry #biotechjobs #interviewtips #interviewquestions #interviewskills #womeninstem #researcher #biology #biologystudent #microbiology #biochemistry #cellbiology

It will happen to you. It will also be okay.

If you’re struggling with failing experiments, try to think about it as an opportunity. Relish the chance to design a troubleshooting experiment, because what you learn might be just as interesting as what you hoped to learn from your failed experiment. Most importantly, don’t get discouraged! It’s not your failures that define you, it’s how you address them.

Instead of focusing on the end goal of your project and how far away you are  from achieving that, you should force yourself to focus your thinking on new, smaller questions. 

This shift in mindset will bring both relief and a new appreciation for the process of troubleshooting. The thinking should no longer be “I need to fix my method so I can test my project’s hypothesis.” It should be “why is this protein so difficult to purify, and what can I learn about it as a result? 

Remember we are all humans, nothing will be perfect at first. What makes you different is how you react and grow from these situations.

🌟 To all my fellow aspiring scientists out there: your journey might seem like a complicated formula, but remember, every scientist started with questions, not answers. The key is to keep asking and keep exploring. You’ve got the ingredients for success – curiosity, resilience, and passion. Don’t let anyone or anything dim your scientific spark. The world needs your discoveries, so keep pushing forward and making your dreams a reality. 🚀🔬

Keep your heads up, and believe you can. I sometimes feel like I just want to quit everything and leave. But I always remind myself why I started in the first place 🫶

🌍 You know, the world can sometimes feel like a tough place, with a lot of negativity around. But here’s the thing: you don’t have to let all that get to you.

💪 You are strong, way stronger than you might think. Even when things get tough and people doubt you, you can keep going.

✨ In a world that sometimes feels pretty gloomy, you can be a bright light. You can stay true to yourself, keep believing in your dreams, and show that you’re positive and full of hope.

💡 You have something special inside you that lets you rise above the negativity. It’s what makes you keep going even when the world says you can’t.

🚀 So, don’t let all the negative stuff get you down. Stay strong, believe in yourself, and remember that you’re capable of doing amazing things. The world needs your positivity and your belief in yourself. Keep being awesome! 💫

This is your sign to do that thing you were procrastinating ✨

If you’re finding it hard to get started on something you’ve been putting off, you’re not alone. Procrastination is a common challenge. But here’s how you can regain your motivation:

1. Take It Step by Step: Break the big task into smaller, doable parts.

2. Set a Deadline: Give yourself a reasonable deadline to create a sense of urgency.

3. Remember Why: Think about why the task matters and how it connects to your goals.

4. Imagine Success: Picture how great it’ll feel when you finish. It can be a powerful motivator.

5. Get Accountability: Share your goal with someone who can help you stay on track.

6. Change Your Space: Sometimes, a change of scenery can boost your motivation.

7. Take Short Breaks: Plan brief breaks during your work to stay fresh and motivated.

8. Reward Yourself: Treat yourself when you accomplish a part of the task. It’s a nice incentive.

9. Stay Positive: Replace those negative thoughts with positive ones. Remind yourself that you can do it.

10. Start Small: If you’re having trouble starting, commit to working on the task for just a few minutes. Often, this is all you need to get going.

So, don’t be too hard on yourself. Procrastination happens to the best of us, but with these strategies, you can get back on track and reach your goals.

Day in the life working in Biotech Boston 🧫🔬

It’s really important to have a life outside of the lab. I know sometimes it can be exhausting but prioritizing yourself and what makes you happy is more important ✨

What makes me happy, is putting on a cute workout set and working out in the morning. Then rewarding myself with a burger 🍔 after a long lab day 🥼 🧫 

On the to do list: 
- Workout 
- Get ready for work 
- Lab work: Transfection, Splitting Cells, PCR 
- Capital Burger for Dinner ( #balanceeating ). 

What makes you happy outside of the lab? 👇

How do I count my cells 🧫? We use a NucleoCounter®️ NC-200™️

There are many methods where you can count cells, but today I am walking you through how to use the NC-200. 

NC-200 is widely used in laboratory as an automated cell counter. 

Keep in mind there are two cassettes to use, Via1-Cassette and Via2-Cassette. In our lab we have been using Via2-Cassette. 

This is a general overview of how to use the NC-200. Save this for later 🔖

Working in STEM fields, especially Biotech is NOT AN END TO YOUR CAREER OR A USELESS FIELD 🚫🙅‍♀️

Earase the stigma of if you are not a physician than you won’t be able to make a difference in the world or help patients 👩‍⚕️

Biotech or other stem careers offers more than just “lab work” you get to make a difference in the world 🌍 

You get to create medicines and therapies that physcians actullay prescribe to their patients! 

You discover things that no one knew existed 🔬 

I was an unaware of how much of a difference I get to make in my job! That brings me more joy than anything 😁

Be proud of where you are and know there are more STEM careers than just being a physician 👩‍⚕️

I know some of you are like why even bother 😂

I love doing my hair in the morning, it makes me feel put together 💁‍♀️

But the downside of working in the lab is that you gotta tie your hair, so al my hard work from the morning is gone 😂

A girl gotta do what a girl gotta do 💁‍♀️ It’s just one of those things that women in stem have to deal with 🙋‍♀️😂

#gloves #labgloves #labwork #lablife🔬 #biotech #biotechusa #biotechnology #labequipment #labhack #tipsandtricks #biology #microbiologist #biologist #biologistlife #biochemist #pov #stem #stemeducation #womeninstem #pharma #biologymeme #stemmemes

I learned that the best way to get something you want is to ask for it ✨

No one is going to read what’s on your mind, if you don’t tell them what you want 🚨

My goal was to get a promotion this year. First thing I did was go talk to my manager about the possibility of getting a promotion and if he thinks I’m at the stage to get one 🙌

‼️ Just a side note: Having a great manager who’ll support you and know your worth is soooo important ‼️

After being on the same page, we put a game plan to execute it and show the people who decide who gets a promotion that I am worth it and that I am ready for a new role 😊

Remember communication in the work field is SOOO important! You have to have these conversations ✨
🧬

⚖️ Here are my tips we should carry into the new year for maintaining work-life balance: 

1. Time-Blocking Technique: Divide your day into set time blocks for each task. Allocate specific hours for work and distinct periods for personal activities. This helps balance focused work with essential personal time.

2. Set Realistic Goals: Avoid overloading yourself. Remember, perfection isn’t the goal. Achievable targets lead to sustainable success.

3. Rest is Crucial: Prioritize good sleep. It’s key for productivity, stress management, and emotional well-being.

4. Discover a Passion: Engage in hobbies outside work. This creates a healthy divide between professional and personal life.

🔬 DM 🫶 so I can send you a FREE planner that I will be using to plan my days. Let’s make 2024 a year of balanced achievements!

We all start somewhere 🔬

I think we all stop at premed and look at ourselves as failures for not going to medschool. But that is not true. 

We all have a journey and our passions get to change along that journey. If I wasn’t brave enough to say I didn’t want to go to medschool then I think I wouldn’t be here with this page helping you have a leg in the door of biotech 🚪

Everything happens for a reason, just believe in yourself ✨

Day in the life working in Biotech Boston 🧬

Morning Schedule ☀️:
- Workout 
- Go to work 
- Drink Coffee 
- Plan out my days and check for emails 

Afternoon 🕛:
- Get ready for Lab 
- Lab work incudes: Changing Media, splitting cells, and a transfection 

Evening 🌙: 
- Go home and unwinds

It’s sometimes so hard to catch up when you are trying to pump out A LOT of data 📊 

The turn around of experiments is so quick that sometimes it takes a minute to circle back and draw out a proper schematic conclusion ✍️

I run so many experiments in one week, that I reach the end of the week barely having time to analyze my experiments 🧫 

Some analyzing I do:
🧫 Flowjo analysis
🧫 PCR analysis 
🧫 Gel analysis (sometimes) 

What are ways you analyze your data? 
🧬
